awd_abstract_narration:
This project envisions two main objectives: First, it studies the theory of geometric representations of graphs, building on a broad array of mathematical methods, and integrating the results into new technology. Second, it trains the next generation of students for careers in mathematics, sciences, and engineering, focusing on solid foundations in discrete mathematics, and developing mathematical skills for handling geometric objects efficiently. Visualizing complex systems and large data sets has become routine, including user-friendly handling of virtual objects in low dimensions. Designing efficient computer tools in this context is a challenging task, it calls for a thorough understanding of how geometric objects and relations between them are represented, as well as highly qualified developers and scientists who are familiar with the capabilities and limitations of these mathematical tools.

Representing graphs in space is constrained by topological, metric, and algebraic properties. Topological constraints are typically captured by unavoidable patterns in the intersection graph of curves or surfaces, and is closely related to Ramsey-type results in combinatorial geometry. Metric constraints correspond to patterns in distances, slopes, angles, and areas that can be realized simultaneously. Algebraic constraints play an important role when edges are represented by algebraic curves (including straight lines). This project will study the intersection patterns of geometric objects, where the intersection relation is represented by an undirected graph, and it will also examine the intersections created by embeddings of geometric graphs, topological graphs, hypergraphs, or simplicial complexes into Euclidean spaces of low dimensions. Related enumerative problems will be considered, as well, where metric and topological constraints combined with classical combinatorial problems yield new challenges. Quantitative bounds for the realization spaces of basic geometric objects (such as points, line segments, lines, and quadrics) have applications in cartography, computer science, optimization, and solid modelling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied a broad range of problems in combinatorial geometry and geometric graph theory. This report highlights four notable results. The celebrated Erdős-Szekeres theorem (1935) gives an asymptotically tight bound on the minimum number of points in convex position in any finite set in the plane. However, generalization to higher dimensions remained elusive. The project obtained a tight bound on the minimum number of points in convex position in a d-dimensional Cartesian product of  finite points, in every dimension d.Answering a question by Conway (1969), the project constructed a convex polytopes in 3-space that can approximate the unit ball arbitrarily closely, and has only one stable face, in the sense that if the polytope is placed on a horizontal surface standing on a face, other than the stable face, it would roll over. Furthermore, it constructed such polytopes with unit diameter that can roll to any distance from an initial position, following the laws of physics; thereby laying the foundation of geometric design of autonomous robots. Chung and Graham (1983) constructed, for every positive integer n, a universal graph that contains every tree on n vertices, and has asymptotically the minimum number of edges. Using asymptotically the same number of edges, this project extended the result to geometric graphs, where the rotation order of all edges incident to each vertex must be respected. The project obtained new results on the intersection pattern of convex bodies, as well. Motivated by wireless communication networks, researcher studied the intersection graph of unit disks in the plane, and asked for a subgraphs that approximate shortest distances in the graph up to a factor t distortion---such a subgraph is called a t-spanner. The project showed that the intersection graph of unit disks in the plane admit a 2-spanner with linearly many edges, which is the best possible. The problem has been generalized to other classes of geometric objects. The design of optimal t-spanners has lead to the discovery of new structural results of geometric intersections graphs.


The project trained undergraduate and graduate students for careers in mathematics and computer science, provided solid foundations in discrete mathematics and geometry, and developed mathematical skills for manipulating and visualizing geometric objects.
